fields.description:
*Assessment*

In Eucalyptus 4.0.1, it takes ~30 seconds for a Eucalyptus ELB to failover traffic from an instance being terminated to a running instance thats registered with the ELB.  This doesn't match AWS ELB behavior. 

Current Eucalyptus behavior seems to relate to EUCA-9919.

*Details*

If a curl test is used to grab the header of the ELB DNS name, when the instance is terminated, the following is returned:
{code}
$ while true; do curl -I flasklb-408396244283.elb.acme.eucalyptus-systems.com; sleep 1; done
.....
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.6.1 (Ubuntu)
Date: Sun, 07 Sep 2014 18:35:28 GMT
Content-Type: text/html
Content-Length: 612
Last-Modified: Tue, 05 Aug 2014 11:18:35 GMT
ETag: "53e0bd8b-264"
Accept-Ranges: bytes

curl: (52) Empty reply from server
curl: (7) Failed connect to flasklb-408396244283.elb.acme.eucalyptus-systems.com:80; Connection refused
curl: (7) Failed connect to flasklb-408396244283.elb.acme.eucalyptus-systems.com:80; Connection refused
{code}

On both Eucalyptus and AWS, the following steps were done:
# Create the ELB
# Create the instances with nginx installed
# Make sure port 80 was open, with the following CIDR rule - 0.0.0.0/0
# Register the instances with the ELB
# Start the 'curl' test against the DNS name of the ELB
# Terminate one of  the instances
# Monitor 'curl' test

*Signs*

* output of 'curl' test on Eucalyptus:
{code}
$ while true; do curl -I flasklb-408396244283.elb.acme.eucalyptus-systems.com; sleep 1; done

*Steps*

# Set up a Eucalyptus 4.0.1 Cloud with Eucalyptus DNS, Cloudformation and Load Balancer enabled
# Bundle, upload and register an [Ubuntu Cloud Image (Utopic 14.10)|http://cloud-images.ubuntu.com/utopic/current/utopic-server-cloudimg-amd64-disk1.img] as instance store-backed HVM EMI.
# Launch an ELB
# Launch 2 instances using the Ubuntu image, and passing the cloud-init.config file below - to install nginx.
{code}
$ cat nginx-cloudinit.config
#cloud-config
apt_update: true
apt_upgrade: true
disable_root: true
packages:
 - less
runcmd:
 - [ sh, -xc, "META_HOSTNAME=`curl -s http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/local-hostname`; META_IP=`curl -s http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/local-ipv4`; echo ${META_IP}   ${META_HOSTNAME} >> /etc/hosts" ]
 - [ sh, -xc, "META_HOSTNAME=`curl -s http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/local-hostname`; hostname ${META_HOSTNAME}; sysctl -w kernel.hostname=${META_HOSTNAME}" ]
 - [ apt-get, install, -y, --force-yes, dnsutils ]
 - [ apt-get, install, -y, --force-yes, bind9utils ]
 - [ apt-get, install, -y, --force-yes, mlocate ]
 - [ apt-get, install, -y, --force-yes, nginx ]
{code}
# Make sure port 80 is open in the security group associated with the instances - for 0.0.0.0/0
# Register the instances with the ELB
# Run the 'curl' test in another terminal.  Use the ELB DNS name in the test.  For example:
{code}
# while true; do curl -I <ELB DNS name>; sleep 1; done
{code}
# Terminate one of the registered instances associated with the ELB
# Observe the output of the 'curl' test

*Workaround*

None so far, however, there could be a solution based upon a specific [HAProxy configuration|http://cbonte.github.io/haproxy-dconv/configuration-1.5.html].
fields.summary: Eucalyptus ELB backend failover performance doesn't match AWS ELB
fields.environment:
* non-HA, multiple-clusters, DNS, Cloudformation, Load Balancer Enabled
** 1 x CLC, DNS, Cloudformation
** 1 x UFS
** 1 x UFS, Walrus
** 2 x CC (Managed), SC
*** cluster 1 - SC (Overlay)
*** cluster 2 - SC (DAS)
** 2 x NCs per cluster

comments.body: [~hspencer] Thanks for reporting this problem. The fix will reduce the failover time to around 5 seconds. The ELB will continue to respond with 503 (for about 5 sec) when the backend instance stop listening to the port.

[~spark],

Thanks for checking this out.  Is there a particular reason why 5 seconds is being used?  Is there any particular thing that can be done to make sure failover happens immediately - like the experience witnessed with AWS ELB?

[~hspencer] There's disconnection between the instance's status (as seen through ec2 api) goes to shutting-down and ELB gives this info to LB VM. Currently, LB VM polls every 10 seconds to get any update from ELB front-end. Shortening the time would get the failover bit faster, but would incur more overhead.

I think in this case, the AWS's behavior is influenced by the termination of instances, not the health check. If I recall correctly, the default heath check interval is much longer (and the threshold value is not 'seconds' but 'times (x)').

Perhaps more interesting test would be to kill the web server process of the backend instances, and see the difference between AWS and Euca's ELB response. If they differ, we should create another ticket. In our implementation, we keep the backend instances listed on the haproxy config until health check fails. Then haproxy returns 503 until the instances are removed from the config. AWS might do it differently.

[~hspencer] If you're asking the case where backend instances are terminated while behind ELB, yes the behavior is slightly different. I believe this won't be really an issue for most of users because the right procedure to retire an instance is to deregister it from the ELB first and to terminate. Only that way ELB and Euca guarantee a predictable behavior.

[~spark],

Verified the issue is fixed.  I tested the fix in two ways:
# a while loop, where a {{curl -I <ELB DNS NAME>}} is performed every second
# a while loop, where a {{curl -I <ELB DNS NAME>}} is performed less than a second
The first test case ran just fine.  Terminated one of the instances associated with the ELB, and all requests returned HTTP/1.1 200.  
The second test case ran _almost_ perfect.  There was one "HTTP/1.0 503 Service Unavailable":
{code}
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.4.6 (Ubuntu)
Date: Fri, 23 Jan 2015 00:56:33 GMT
Content-Type: text/html
Content-Length: 612
Last-Modified: Tue, 04 Mar 2014 11:46:45 GMT
ETag: "5315bd25-264"
Accept-Ranges: bytes

HTTP/1.0 503 Service Unavailable
Cache-Control: no-cache
Connection: close
Content-Type: text/html

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.4.6 (Ubuntu)
Date: Fri, 23 Jan 2015 00:56:45 GMT
Content-Type: text/html
Content-Length: 612
Last-Modified: Tue, 04 Mar 2014 11:46:45 GMT
ETag: "5315bd25-264"
Accept-Ranges: bytes
{code}
however, I think this is satisfactory.  

Eucalyptus Version:  4.1.0-0.0.23023.353.20150116git0f5f4f1.el6

*Steps*

# Using the admin user of a given account, do the following:
## Bundle, upload and register an instance store-backed [HVM Ubuntu Trusty Cloud image|http://images.objectstorage.cloud.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/trusty-server-cloudimg-amd64-disk1-20150115.img]
## Create a keypair
# Use the attached cloudformation template (cfn-euca9965-template.json), with the admin user of a given account to create a cloudformation stack in one availability zone, which will deploy an ELB tied to an autoscaling group of Nginx web servers:
{code}
 euform-create-stack ELBAutoScaleNginxV2 --template-file cfn-euca9965-template.json --parameter "UbuntuImageId=emi-38abe905" --parameter "UserKeyPair=admin-hspencer1" --parameter "Zone=two" --region admin-hspencer@group1
arn:aws:cloudformation::439629811643:stack/ELBAutoScaleNginxV2/75c70d6c-55b5-4835-9481-66854d910b76
{code}
# Confirm the stack deploys successfully:
{code}
# euform-describe-stacks --region admin-hspencer@group1
STACK	ELBAutoScaleNginxV2	CREATE_COMPLETE	Complete!	AWS CloudFormation Sample Template AutoScalingMultiAZWithNotifications: Create a multi-az, load balanced and Auto Scaled sample web site running on an Nginx Web Serever. The application is configured to span in one availability zone (one cluster) and is Auto-Scaled based on the CPU utilization of the web servers.	2015-01-23T00:50:21.866Z
OUTPUT	URL	http://ELBAutoS-ElasticLo-6APNDXMDW5M61-439629811643.lb.h-12.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
{code}
# Run the test case mentioned in the ticket using curl in a separate terminal window:
{code}
$ while true; do curl -I http://ELBAutoS-ElasticLo-6APNDXMDW5M61-439629811643.lb.h-12.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com; sleep 1; done
{code}
# Terminate one of the instances registered to the ELB:
{code}
# euca-describe-instances --region admin-hspencer@group1 --filter tag-key=aws:cloudformation:stack-name --filter tag-value=ELBAutoScaleNginxV2
